data.title: A Guide to the Most Scenic Films Shot in Greece
data.meta_description: From Michael Cacoyannis’s famed Zorba the Greek to the beachy musical that is Mamma Mia!, these are our favorite Greece-set films.
data.text:
From Michael Cacoyannis’s famed Zorba the Greek to the beachy musical that is Mamma Mia!, these are our favorite Greece-set films. For more Travel via Cinema destinations, click here.

Before Midnight, 2013

Richard Linklater

The third and final film in Richard Linklater’s trilogy, Before Midnight finds Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke reminiscing about their love and life together on holiday in Greece. They're on the Peloponnese peninsula, where they spend their evening together, watching the sun set the sky ablaze in orange before it dips into the dusky sea.

To watch, click here.

Boy on a Dolphin, 1957

Jean Negulesco

This was the first Hollywood film shot in Greece, and Italian actress Sophia Loren’s English-language debut as a dazzling sponge diver. Loren discovers a sunken ship off the coast of the Aegean Sea filled with priceless treasures, including an ancient gold statue of a boy on a dolphin. Archaeologist Alan Ladd and antiques dealer Clifton Webb vie for both her attention and the artifact. All this is set against the backdrop of the mystical island of Hydra.

To watch, click here.

Eternity and a Day, 1998

Theo Angelopoulos

Never on Sunday, 1960

Jules Dassin

In this romantic comedy, Ilya is a free-spirited Greek prostitute living in the port of Piraeus. She’s out on the town—downing ooza and dancing the Sirtaki with a different gentleman friend—every day except for, as the title suggests, Sunday. Its star, Melina Mercouri, won best actress for playing Ilya at the 1960 Cannes Film Festival.

To watch, click here.

Phaedra, 1962

Jules Dassin

Phaedra (Melina Mercouri), the wife of a shipping tycoon, wants for nothing—except for her husband’s son (Anthony Perkins) from his first marriage, who she instantly falls in love with. The two begin an affair, which has devastating results. It’s a bit of a Greek tragedy but there are magnificent moments of island life (Hydra) along the way.

To watch, click here.
